Back: The study of past events and people.
Evidence created at the time of an event.
Evidence written later about an event.

Front: Give an example of a primary source.
Back: A diary, photograph or letter.

Front: Give an example of a secondary source.
Back: A textbook or documentary.
Information about the origin of a source.

Front: What does reliability mean in history?
Back: How trustworthy a source is.

Front: What does usefulness mean in history?
Back: How helpful a source is for an enquiry.
A one-sided or unfair viewpoint.
A view or explanation of the past.
Different evidence, viewpoints or purposes.
How important an event or person was.
The reasons why something happened.
A cause close in time to an event.
A cause that develops over many years.
What happened as a result of an event.
Things that stayed the same over time.
Things that became different over time.
Events arranged in time order.
A visual display of events in order.
England between around 1000 and 1500.
A system where land was exchanged for loyalty.

Front: Who was at the top of the feudal system?
Back: The king.

Front: What was the role of a medieval lord?
Back: To protect land and provide soldiers.

Front: What was the role of peasants?
Back: To farm the land.
A deadly plague that hit England in 1348.
Bacteria spread by fleas on rats.

Front: One consequence of the Black Death?
Back: Population fell dramatically.
A period of renewed interest in learning and art.
Changes to the Christian Church in the 1500s.
King of England from 1509 to 1547.

Front: Why did Henry VIII break from Rome?
Back: To divorce Catherine of Aragon.

Front: What was the Church of England?
Back: The new Protestant church led by the monarch.

Front: What was the English Civil War?
Back: A war between Parliament and the King.

Front: When did the English Civil War take place?

Back: Supporters of Parliament.
Supporters of the King.
He was executed in 1649.
A period of rapid industrial change.

Front: When did the Industrial Revolution begin?
Back: Around 1750.
The textile industry.
Movement of people from countryside to towns.
Overcrowding and poor housing.
Children working long hours in factories.
A law to improve working conditions.
Countries controlled by Britain.
Forcing people to work without pay or freedom.

Front: When was slavery abolished in Britain?

Back: A global war fought from 1914 to 1918.
Militarism, alliances, imperialism and nationalism.

Front: What was the Treaty of Versailles?
Back: The peace treaty ending World War One.

Front: Why was the Treaty of Versailles unpopular in Germany?
Back: It blamed and punished Germany.

Money losing value very quickly.
A worldwide economic crisis starting in 1929.
Leader of Nazi Germany.
A far-right political party in Germany.
He was appointed in 1933.
Information used to influence opinions.
Nazi secret police.
Camps where people were imprisoned.
The murder of six million Jews.
A global war fought from 1939 to 1945.
Germany invading Poland in 1939.
German bombing of British cities.
Moving children away from cities for safety.
Limiting supplies of food and goods.
The Allied invasion of Normandy in 1944.

Front: What happened at the end of World War Two?
Back: Germany surrendered in 1945.
Tension between USA and USSR after WWII.
The divide between communist and capitalist Europe.
A wall dividing East and West Berlin.

Front: When did the Berlin Wall fall?

Back: A system where people vote for leaders.
A system ruled by one person.
A vote on an issue by the public.
Information used to support an argument.

Front: What makes a strong historical answer?
Back: Clear knowledge supported by evidence.
Explain causes and consequences using evidence.
